qas.question: What was King George II's royal residence beginning in 1762?
What was the name of the police force established in London in 1750?
On average, when did children born in the City of London die?
How many crimes in 18th century London could result in the death penalty?
What was the London hub of the British press?

context: In 1762, George III acquired <a0_0>Buckingham House<a0_0/> and it was enlarged over the next 75 years. During the 18th century, London was dogged by crime, and <a1_0>the Bow Street Runners<a1_0/> were established in 1750 as a professional police force. In total, <a3_0>more than 200<a3_0/> offences were punishable by death, including petty theft. Most children born in the city died <a2_0>before reaching their third birthday<a2_0/>. The coffeehouse became a popular place to debate ideas, with growing literacy and the development of the printing press making news widely available; and <a4_0>Fleet Street<a4_0/> became the centre of the British press.
